h3. Summary

Two *atlassian-synchrony.log* files are created and populated when running in DC and Synchrony is in self-managed mode.

h3. Environment

* Confluence 6.12.0 or up in DC mode
* Synchrony in self-managed mode (started and administrated by Confluence)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Start the DC node
# Check the following directories:
#* *<Confluence-Home>/logs/*
#* *<Confluence-Home>/*

h3. Expected Results

The *atlassian-synchrony.log* file can only be found under *<Confluence-Home>/logs/*.

h3. Actual Results

We can see two *atlassian-synchrony.log*, one in *<Confluence-Home>/logs/* and the other under *<Confluence-Home>/*.
 
h3. Notes

Both files log the same information, so it is just a problem of redundancy. The only difference is the formatting:

# *<Confluence-Home>/logs/atlassian-synchrony.log* uses log4j formatting
# *<Confluence-Home>/atlassian-synchrony.log* uses JSON formatting

By inspecting the Synchrony source code, we notice that the second log file above is created here:

{code}
(defn init-additional-logger
  "Adds logs file appender when synchrony is running btf"
  []
  (when-not (external-log4jconfig-provided)
    (when (is-mode "hazelcast-btf")
    ...
{code} 

Based on this snippet, it seems that the flag *external-log4jconfig-provided* is not getting set to true, even though we have log4j settings for Synchrony inside *<Confluence-Install>/confluence/WEB-INF/classes/log4j.properties*. This ends up triggering the extra log appender.

h3.Workaround

# Edit the file  *<Confluence-Home>/synchrony-args.properties*
# Add the following line to this file:
{code}
log4j.configuration=somefile
{code}
(!) somefile is just a dummy name, the file does not need to actually exist on the file system.
# Go to *Cog Icon > General Configuration > Collaborative Editing* and *Restart Synchrony*

Once those steps are executed, the file *<Confluence-Home>/atlassian-synchrony.log* will no longer be populated and can be safely deleted. The only Synchrony log that will be used after that is *<Confluence-Home>/logs/atlassian-synchrony.log*.
fields.summary: Duplicate atlassian-synchrony.log files are created when running in Data Center mode

fields.description:
{panel:title=Issue Partially Fixed}
The root cause of this issue has been addressed in the following versions of Confluence:
 * Enterprise release 6.6.x stream: Confluence 6.6.12+
 * Enterprise release 6.13.x stream: Confluence 6.13.1+
 * Regular release stream: Confluence 6.14.0+

Please do note, however, that this is a data corruption issue. If you are on one of the releases mentioned above, new data corruption will not occur, but existing stale drafts that have had their modification date wrongly updated will continue to show. We are currently working on an upgrade task to fix this. Please see CONFSERVER-58285. In the mean time, the workaround  mentioned below can be applied on a page by page basis.
{panel}
h4. Issue Summary

In some cases, After clicking on the _Edit_ button of a page, the user has the impression of editing an old version of it.
 Checking the content of the current published page and the content that appears while editing it, they are different, but seems to match exactly what it was in one of the previous versions.

For example, this is the content of the latest published version of a page while on the _view mode_:
 !current-page.png|thumbnail! 
 When clicking on the _Edit_ button, this is the content you get while on the _editing mode_:
 !editing-page.png|thumbnail!

This only occurs when Collaborative Editing (CE) is enabled.
 If you *disable* CE, and edit the same page, then you get the current content in the _edit mode_, such as the image below:
 !editing-page-full.png|thumbnail!

This only affects some pages on a very specific situation (which is described in the next session), meaning that you don't see this behavior on all pages of the Confluence instance.

This issue was confirmed in versions *6.6.3* and *6.12.1*, meaning that it may affect any version with Collaborative Editing before and including *6.12.1*.
h4. How to Reproduce the Issue
 # Have a Confluence instance configured with CE enabled.
 # Create a blank space.
 ** Space Name: _Space A_.
 ** Space Key: _SPACEA_.
 # Create another blank space.
 ** Space Name: _Space 1_.
 ** Space Key: _SPACE1_.
 # In _Space 1_, create a blank page with title _Page 1_.
 !page1_img001.png|thumbnail!
 # In _Space A_, create a page named _Page A_.
 ** Add any content you like, but make sure to include a [link|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/links-776656293.html] to _Page 1_.
 !pageA_img001.png|thumbnail!
 # Start editing _Page A_, but don't publish the contents, save it for later.
 !pageA_img002.png|thumbnail!
 # For now we have the following scenario:
 ** Collaborative Editing enabled.
 ** _Space 1_ with page _Page 1_.
 ** _Space A_ with page _Page A_ with a link to _Page 1_ as part of its contents.
 ** A draft of _Page A_ with _unpublished changes_.
 ** If we check the {{CONTENT}} table for _Page A_, there are 2 records, one for the page and the other related to its draft.
 !pageA_img003.png|thumbnail!
 # [Turn CE *off*|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/administering-collaborative-editing-858772086.html#AdministeringCollaborativeEditing-Changetheeditingmode] using the Confluence UI.
 # Start editing _Page A_ again and publish the modifications.
 ** Since CE is off, it will not use the modifications that were in the shared draft.
 !pageA_img004.png|thumbnail!
 # If we check the {{CONTENT}} table for _Page A_, now we have 3 records.
 !pageA_img005.png|thumbnail!
 # Move _Page 1_ from _Space 1_ to any other Space, such as _Space A_.
 !page1_img002.png|thumbnail!
 # If you check the storage format of _Page A_, the source related to the link to _Page 1_ has changed.
 !pageA_img006.png|thumbnail!
 # If you check the {{lastmoddate}} value of _Page A_'s draft, it was changed.
 ** Note that the {{lastmoddate}} value of the current version hasn't changed.
 !pageA_img007.png|thumbnail!
 # [Turn CE *on*|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/administering-collaborative-editing-858772086.html#AdministeringCollaborativeEditing-Changetheeditingmode] using the Confluence UI.
 # Start to edit _Page A_ and it will use the shared draft of the old version, prior to disabling CE.
 !pageA_img008.png|thumbnail!

h4. Expected Behavior
 # When editing a page with CE enabled, Confluence gives you a draft based on the last version of the page.
 # Move page actions doesn't update the shared draft if the {{lastmoddate}} of the shared draft is older than the published page.
 ** No matter if CE is off or on, Confluence should compare the timestamp of the current page version and the draft.

h4. Workaround

If you identify a page is using the wrong shared draft, you can discard the draft as follows:
 # Click on the _Edit_ button of the page.
 # Add any modification to the page and click on the _Close_ button at the bottom right of the editor.
 # In the _Close the editor_ pop-up, select _Discard all changes_.
 ** (!) If you discard changes, your unpublished changes will be deleted. You can't undo this action.
fields.summary: Editing a page with Collaborative Editing enabled might show an older version of that page

h4. Problem Statment
There is no background job that runs to check the health of Index on Confluence. Several customers have faced corrupt Index issue many times. 

h4. Suggestion
It would be beneficial to write a job that would run as a background process and perform a consistency check on the index on a periodic basis to determine the index health. If the index was deemed unhealthy it could alert the admin that a reindex was needed or attempt to correct the index.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Even after [restricting a user's ability to use the people directory or perform a quick search|https://confluence.atlassian.com/confkb/how-to-restrict-users-from-accessing-people-directory-or-search-users-from-quick-search-688883545.html], a user can still use the REST API to locate another user's information:
{code}
rest/api/search?cql=text~"a name
{code}

h3. Suggested Solution
We cannot restrict the API entirely as Confluence uses the same REST API for it's processes as noted in [CONFSERVER\-7913: Need ability to limit use of remote API to certain users, or a certain group|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-7913]. However, it would be useful to be able to restrict certain users or groups from receiving user results.

We have the [CONFSERVER\-7837: People Directory and "controlled" privacy / configure access to People Directory depending on Group membership|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-7837] feature request, however, this feature doesn't include results that can be pulled from the REST API.
fields.summary: Allow restriction of user results from showing up in quick search and rest API searches for certain users or groups

h3. Notes

From my investigation, the regex of _Include Headings_ works as follows.

h4. In preview:
Confluence uses the regex to match *substring* of each heading

h4. In page itself:
Confluence uses the regex to match *head* of each heading

It means, if we would like to match only "BCD" in the page itself, we need to use {{^B.+}} or {{^B}} instead.

h3. Workaround

Please try to use regex to match *head* of each heading.

h3. Problem Definition
Confluence uses document conversion service to convert Office file and PDF files for preview and thumbnail generation. Currently, this service has a queue of tasks to run through and the file conversion service spins up background threads to convert those documents. Unfortunately, if one document is taking a bit more time to convert, Confluence might spin too many concurrent threads which might add too much pressure on the CPU and memory.

h3. Suggested Solution
The suggested solution is to limit the number of concurrent conversion threads by default.


h3. Workaround
The current workaround is to add the following JVM argument to limit the number of conversion threads.
{code}
-Dconfluence.document.conversion.threads=3
{code}
fields.summary: Limit the number of document conversion threads by default

fields.description:
Today a page (not counting shortened urls) can have two types of URLs:
 # [https://confluence.example.com/display/SPACEKEY/Page+Title]
 # [https://confluence.example.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=123456]

*The former format (1)* gives hints the user about the content of the page. This is extra great when you send several links to a user, since it often removes the need to write a description for each of the links.

However, since the URL can change at any given moment. Making the format useless for long term usage.

*The latter format (2)* is permanent,** but extremely user unfriendly. When sending links of this kind, the sender must always include description of the links.

It is also not clear for the vast majority of the end users why a certain URL is generated in a certain way (some power users may know, but it not common).

I propose a *new default URL format* for pages on confluence. Allow a middle chunk in the URL to contain meta-data that *_is not used_* when retrieving the page:
{quote}{{[https://confluence.example.com/p/Page+Title/123456|https://confluence.example.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=123456]}}
{quote}
Since the only parts used for page retrieval would be /p/*/123456 you would not risk the URL to stop working, but the receiver could still figure out what it is about by reading the link.

*Page titles with special characters could now be sanitised and included in the generated URLs. The retrieval would still work.*

Looking at other services, this is a quite common way to solve this exact issue, and as an extra bonus, the URLs are far more SEO friendly.
fields.summary: New URL format proposal (permanent URLs that include meta-data)

Previewing large Excel files in Confluence can cause Out of Memory Errors as well as High CPU Usage, leading the application to freeze until the document is converted or, in worst scenarios, to get unresponsive until it has been restarted.
h2. Previous Bugs

There has been fixed bugs related to File Conversion Services in the past:
 * CONFSERVER-46542
 * CONFSERVER-52279

||Confluence version ||Document Library  Version||

 # Access Confluence as an Administrator.
 # Click on the Cog Icon in your Right Upper Corner and then click on Add-ons.

In instances where nodes have *not had downtime* or required a restart, but the index has been rebuilt on one node, automatically replicating the index in the background to the other nodes is useful to administrators who wish to maximize uptime. 

If a manual index rebuild is triggered, it should be sufficient to flag that node's index as the most current copy for replication to the other nodes without downtime.

* [Administer Your Data Center Search Index|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/administer-your-data-center-search-index-879956107.html]

(related to I18n, Internationalization, Localization)

*Requirements*
 * Pages should be able to have multiple versions per language.
 * Search results should display the versions of articles in user's logged-in language. This should apply when using the search from the Service Desk portals as well.
 * When viewing a page, a user should see links to the different language versions (like Wikipedia does.)
 * The translated pages should know which language should be considered the "primary language". The primary language should have a Space-level default and be switchable per page.
 * When a user views a secondary language version, the page should display a warning indicating when the primary version has been updated more recently (i.e. "This page may no longer be current").
 * Admins should be able to see a list of pages which have either not yet been translated into a given locale (e.g. "How to Cook Tacos" is available in English but not Japanese) or have had updates to the primary version.
 * Provide API hooks when a translated page was updated, along with change list (e.g. to facilitate marketplace integration of translation services.)
 * Admins should be able to define locale fallbacks at the space-level, for example, "Simplified Chinese" falls back to "Traditional Chinese" if available, otherwise falls back to "English" (meaning that Chinese users will see English content if the Chinese version isn't available.)
 * Ideally, URLs for other language versions would use the same slug as the primary version, could be something like /my-blog-post?lang=en and /my-blog-post?lang=fr

Wikipedia should be considered a reference for this functionality. There is also a requirement doc from 2006 here [https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?spaceKey=DISC&title=Translation+of+content] which is still relevant.

*Current Workarounds*

Currently, the recommended solution is to make multiple Confluence Spaces, one for each language. This approach is fraught with problems, for example, since one Service Desk can only be linked to one Confluence space, you effectively can't use Service Desks in multiple languages with Confluence.

*Note about Marketplace*

The related tickets CONFCLOUD-1076 / CONFSERVER-1076 were closed 5 years ago with a note saying this would be handled by the marketplace, However, in 5 years the marketplace has not produced a tenable solution in either the cloud or server versions.
 There are some translation management solutions such as Appfusions ([http://www.appfusions.com/display/LNGOTKC/Home]) however these are not substitute for the core issue here, which is that Confluence lacks the proper datastructure. If Atlassian makes the proper datastructure (described above) then it will facilitate more translation solutions (e.g. human, machine, etc) being made available on the marketplace, especially if API hooks are made when content changes.
fields.summary: Confluence: Support multiple page versions per language

fields.description:
The documentation is to revert Crowd or Jira applications to Internal User Management.
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Reverting+from+Crowd+or+Jira+applications+to+Internal+User+Management

Let's say that we have the following in Confluence database:

*cwd_user*
||user_id||username||directory||
|conf_user|Admin|Confluence Internal|
|jira_user|Admin|External JIRA|

*cwd_membership*
||parent_id||child_user_id||
|conf_group1|conf_user|
|jira_group1|jira_user|
|jira_group2|jira_user|

*cwd_group*
||group_id||GroupName||directory||
|conf_group1|confluence-users|Confluence Internal|
|jira_group1|confluence-users|External JIRA|

From the documentation, in the step *Move Groups to Confluence*, 
{code}
update cwd_membership set parent_id=<internal group id> where parent_id=<external group id>;
{code}
with the situation above, this SQL query will update jira_group1 to conf_group_1. Now, the groups looks like follow:

*cwd_membership*
||parent_id||child_user_id||
|conf_group1|conf_user|
|conf_group1|jira_user|
|jira_group2|jira_user|

Moving with the documentation into the *Move Users to Confluence*:
{code}
update cwd_membership set child_user_id=<internal user id> where child_user_id=<external user id>;
{code}
with the with the situation above, the SQL query listed will *attempt* to update jira_user to conf_user. 

Now, this is a problem because, if you see in the previous table, there already exists a |conf_group1|conf_user| pair and this SQL query will attempt to update |conf_group1|jira_user| into |conf_group1|conf_user| which will fail because |conf_group1|conf_user| already exists.

*Please help with*
Altering the SQL queries for the *Move Users to Confluence* bit, to capture instances where there are 2 users with the same username that respectively belong to a group with the same group name.
fields.summary: Update Reverting from Crowd or Jira applications to Internal User Management page to handle when users with same username belong to same group

fields.description:
h1. Background

When Confluence starts up, it verifies schemas for all tables with active objects (AO), and modifies / adds fields if required. For example, if a new version of a plugin is installed, and this plugin introduces a new field in AO class, the corresponding table will be updated and new column will be created.
h1. The problem

For MySQL, migration procedure has a bug and updates several tables on every boot like this:
{code:java}
 [[SQLAction{statement='ALTER TABLE AO_BAF3AA_AOINLINE_TASK CHANGE COLUMN BODY BODY LONGTEXT DEFAULT NULL', undoAction=null}]]


[[SQLAction{statement='ALTER TABLE AO_88BB94_BATCH_NOTIFICATION CHANGE COLUMN PAYLOAD PAYLOAD LONGTEXT NOT NULL', undoAction=null}]]


[[SQLAction{statement='ALTER TABLE AO_21D670_WHITELIST_RULES CHANGE COLUMN EXPRESSION EXPRESSION LONGTEXT NOT NULL', undoAction=null}]]

...etc...{code}
It is not a serious issue for Confluence with one node (it only increases boot time), but in case of 2+ nodes it could lead Confluence to deadlock. Example:
 # The first node is executing slow query (which takes a lot of time) on AO_BAF3AA_AOINLINE_TASK table
 # The second node is being restarted and is trying to modify AO_BAF3AA_AOINLINE_TASK. But this operation is blocked while the first node does not finish all SQL queries on AO_BAF3AA_AOINLINE_TASK
 # The first node tries to run more SQL queries on AO_BAF3AA_AOINLINE_TASK, but all of them are blocked by DDL operation on the second node.

As a result, all threads could be blocked.
h1. Expected behaviour

Confluence should not run any DDL operations on boot if tables do not require changes.
h1. Technical details

It happens in SchemaGenerator.migrate
fields.summary: Confluence modifies tables with active objects on every restart

h3. Summary

Internal directory user's password needs to match the one in Crowd in the following conditions.

* SSO is enabled
* Confluence Internal Directory is in a higher position than Crowd Directory in [User Directories|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/configuring-user-directories-229838212.html] setting

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# [Integrating Crowd with Atlassian Confluence|https://ja.confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/integrating-crowd-with-atlassian-confluence-198573.html]
# Create a user who has same username in in each directory as follows
#* Confluence Internal Directory:
#** username: testuser
#** password: *password1*
#* Crowd Directory:
#** username: testuser
#** password: *password2*
# Move Confluence Internal Directory in a higher position than Crowd Directory in _Confluence administrations > User Directories_
# Enable SSO with following instruction in the above page
# Try to login Confluence with the latter one (in Crowd Directory) credential
#* Please login Confluence from Confluence's login page and do not login from Crowd or the other SSO enabled applications

h3. Expected Results

As [the document|https://ja.confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/integrating-crowd-with-atlassian-confluence-198573.html] said,

bq. It is possible to define multiple user directories in Confluence. However, if you enable Crowd SSO integration, you will only be able to authenticate as users from the Crowd server defined in the crowd.properties file.

the credential in Crowd Directory should be used for the authentication and the login should succeed.

h3. Actual Results

The login failed. Even if we try to login with the credential in Confluence Internal Directory, it failed as well. It means both of the passwords need to match each other.
 
h3. Notes

The user seemed to be authenticated twice by both Jira Internal Directory and Crowd Directory in this situation.

There was also [a suggestion|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-25060] which asked for disabling other directories than Crowd if SSO was enabled but it was already closed as "Won't Fix".

h3.Workaround

We can still login Confluence from other SSO enabled applications' login page.
fields.summary: Internal directory user's password needs to match the one in Crowd if SSO is enabled

# When a new Space is created, as a Software Project Space, a shortcut is created to the Jira Project that the Confluence Space is associated to.

# However, when we *Edit* and update JIRA's base URL in the *Application Link* page, the Space shortcut will still point to the project using the old application link.

h4. Steps to reproduce
# Create a space as Software Project Space and select a JIRA project for it.
# A shortcut will be created in the Confluence Space, to that Project in Jira.
# Change the Jira Base URL.
# Update the application link in Confluence to the new JIRA Base URL.

# Update the URLs from the database.
#* Make sure to create database backup before proceeding with this step.
#* 
{code:java}
UPDATE AO_187CCC_SIDEBAR_LINK SET HARDCODED_URL = REPLACE(HARDCODED_URL,'<OLD_BASE_URL>','<NEW_BASE_URL>');
{code}

h3. Problem Definition
If a user is deactivated and down the road, a new user comes along with the same username. The user will have access to the old username. 

However, this is an expected behavior. Where the old Username access is preserved as it is being deactivated. That being said, this causes a security risk and also confusion in big companies. As Confluence and LDAP admins might not be in the same department when the new LDAP is being created. 

h3. Suggested Solution
A checker or an alert to the admin in Atlassian Product end should be notified before the user is being created automatically if for example a name or an email is mismatched from the old set of LDAP details to determine if the user is activated back correctly or this is a separate user altogether. 

h3. Why this is important
If the previous user is a Manager position and a new user with the same name come along. The new user might have access to certain information that he/she should not.  

h3. Workaround 
Do not use the same username for now.
fields.summary: Embedded Crowd to have a checker for user creation

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
On a super high-level description, Confluence occupies a database connection from the connection pool throughout the entirety of the HTTP request. Once that HTTP request returns, the database connection is returned to the pool.
This is a very complex topic on how Confluence handles database connections. Several enhancements and optimizations were done throughout the years to make sure we don't hold up a database connection for long. However, the first statement still holds. 
When an HTTP request is required to interact with an external system, that database connection will still be held until a response is received from the remote server. In the case where you have a slowness with getting the response, the new incoming HTTP requests will open more database connections in Confluence.

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be nice to have Confluence use a database connection only when it is needed within the lifespan of an HTTP request.

h3. Workaround
Unfortunately, there are no workarounds at the moment.
fields.summary: Confluence should not hold a database connection when it is not needed
